paragraph: BRUTUS: Sheathe your dagger:       Be angry when you will, it shall have scope:       Do what you will, dishonor shall be humor.       _O Cassius, you are yoked with a lamb_       That carries anger as the flint bears fire:       Who, much enforced, shows a hasty spark,       And straight is cold again.CASSIUS:              Hath Cassius liv’d       To be but mirth and laughter to his Brutus       When grief and blood ill-tempered vexeth him?BRUTUS: When I spoke that, I was ill-tempered too.CASSIUS: Do you confess so much? Give me your hand.BRUTUS: And my heart too.CASSIUS:         O Brutus!BRUTUS:               What’s the matter?CASSIUS: Have not you love enough to bear with me        When that rash humor _which my mother gave me_        Makes me forgetful?BRUTUS:           Yes, Cassius, and from henceforth        When you are over earnest with your Brutus,        He’ll think your mother chides and leave you so.
question: Why does Cassius refer to Brutus as being "yoked with a lamb" who carries anger as a flint bears fire?
answer: Cassius refers to Brutus as being "yoked with a lamb" who carries anger as a flint bears fire to highlight that Brutus, despite his gentleness, can occasionally flare up with intense anger that quickly subsides.
